name: Kodak Gold 200
about: A low speed color negative film that offers an outstanding combination of color saturation, fine grain, and high sharpness. Legendary warm tones and high latitude. Optimized for golden hour transitions; reliable for standard landscape work.

name: Flic Film Elektra 100
about: Kodak Aerocolor IV re-spooled. A fine grained medium speed film with excellent acuity and true color rendition. Note that this film has a tendency to 'light pipe'—load in low light. Uses a 1.3 power factor and remains stable for exposures under 2 minutes.

name: Harman Phoenix 200
about: The first ever color film made entirely from emulsion-to-cassette at the HARMAN technology factory. High contrast and strong visible grain with punchy colors. Expect significant contrast shifts and halation in long exposures.

name: Street Candy ATM 400
about: Originally used in ATMs to catch bank robbers. A high-contrast surveillance film with a unique, moody panchromatic look. Data is derived from community consensus testing on re-spooled atmospheric stocks.

name: Fomapan 100 Classic
about: A panchromatically sensitized black-and-white negative film designed for high requirements for low granularity and high resolving power. Reciprocity failure is extreme; a 10s metered time requires roughly 50s exposure.

name: Kodak UltraMax 400
about: A worry-free high speed film designed for snapshooters. Gives you the flexibility you need for consistently better pictures in more picture-taking situations. Standard 1.3 reciprocity exponent; highly reliable up to 30s.

name: Ilford HP5 Plus
about: A high speed, medium contrast black & white film making it an excellent choice for journalism and travel. Reliability is manufacturer-verified, proving highly predictable beyond the 1-second floor.

name: Kentmere Pan 400
about: A flexible high-speed black and white film for everyday use. Offers good sharpness and fine grain. Stable choice for large format testing and outdoor trekking.

name: Kodak ColorPlus 200
about: A versatile film with fine grain and high sharpness. Good for a wide range of lighting conditions. Uses the 1.3 rule of thumb, providing surprising latitude for night street photography.

name: CineStill 800T
about: Designed for difficult low light tungsten situations. Features iconic red halations around light sources. Uses the standard 1.3 power factor; monitor highlight wash-out in exposures exceeding 60s.

name: Flic Film Aurora 800
about: A high-speed color negative re-spooled from Portra 800. Handles extremely low light with character. Requires more aggressive compensation than lower-speed color stocks.

name: Ilford Delta 100 Professional
about: An ultra-sharp black and white film using latest Core-shell™ technology for maximum sharpness. Manufacturer-verified reciprocity ensures stunning results for detail-rich landscapes.

name: Flic Film UltraPan 400
about: A traditional black and white emulsion with classic grain and high versatility. This is re-spooled Fomapan 400 Action. Uses community-corrected reciprocity factors.

name: Street Candy Psychedelic 400
about: A creative specialty color stock with high latitude. Originally a technical film, it offers a unique look. Reliability based on community testing; recommended to bracket in unpredictable light.

name: Ilford FP4 Plus
about: Exceptionally fine-grained, medium-speed black and white film. Reliability is manufacturer-verified and highly efficient for long-exposure pinhole work.

name: Fomapan 200 Creative
about: A modern T-grain/tabular mix that offers a different aesthetic than the 100 Classic. Manufacturer data is verified and shows significantly better reciprocity efficiency.

name: Fomapan 400 Action
about: A versatile high-speed black and white film for use under unfavorable light. Reliability based on community-corrected factors for more accurate shadow detail.

name: Kentmere Pan 100
about: A medium-speed black and white film suitable for a wide variety of applications. Reliability based on community consensus, closely mirroring Ilford FP4+ behavior.

name: FPP Wolfman 100
about: A moody, German-made black and white emulsion re-spooled by the FPP. Provides a unique, cinematic look with rich blacks. Reciprocity behavior is reliable for long-exposure trekking.

name: FPP The Mummy 400
about: An experimental panchromatic black and white film with a distinct grain structure and ancient soul. Reliability based on community consensus for 400-speed emulsions.

name: Kodak Portra 160
about: Features a significantly finer grain structure for improved scanning. Reliability is manufacturer-verified via Kodak F-4040; extremely stable for long-exposure portraiture.

name: Kodak Portra 800
about: High speed film with natural skin tones. Reliable in even the most challenging low-light situations. Requires more aggressive reciprocity compensation than lower speed stocks.

name: Kodak Ektar 100
about: The world's finest-grain color negative film. High saturation and ultra-vivid color make it ideal for nature. High efficiency in reciprocity math via Kodak Publication E-4046.

name: CineStill 400D
about: A daylight-balanced color negative motion picture film prepared for still photography. Cinematic palette with soft skin tones. Uses the standard 1.3 factor recommended by CineStill.

name: CineStill 50D
about: The sharpest color film in the world, originally for motion picture cameras. Boasts unsurpassed grain and contrast. Ideal for bright-day trekking or pinhole work.

name: Ilford Delta 3200 Professional
about: Ultra-high-speed black and white film for action and low-light. Reliability is manufacturer-verified, exhibiting predictable reciprocity curves even at extreme speeds.

name: Ilford XP2 Super 400
about: A sharp, fast black and white film processed in C-41 chemicals. Reliability is at the highest level, mirroring traditional Ilford B&W reciprocity characteristics.

name: Ilford SFX 200
about: Black and white film with extended red sensitivity for creative applications. Use with a deep red filter for near-infrared looks. Reliability is verified by Ilford.

name: Kodak T-MAX P3200
about: Multi-speed continuous-tone black and white negative film. Reliability based on Kodak F-4016, offering predictable performance for professional night work.

name: Fujifilm Neopan 100 Acros II
about: The gold standard for long-exposure photography. No reciprocity correction needed up to 120 seconds. Verified via Fuji data sheets for pinpoint accuracy.

name: Flic Film UltraPan 18
about: Ultra-low speed technical film re-spooled for pictorial use. Perfect for long daylight exposures and blurred motion without heavy ND filters.

name: Adox CHS 100 II
about: Orthopanchromatic black and white film with unique spectral sensitivity that provides beautiful highlight separation. Verified via Adox documentation.

name: Kodak T-MAX 400
about: A continuous tone panchromatic film with high sharpness and very fine grain. Sourced directly from Kodak Data Sheets for high-precision technical work.

name: CineStill BwXX
about: Classic panchromatic B&W negative film relatively unchanged since 1959. Delivers rich blacks and micro-contrast. Reliability level 3 via CineStill guidelines.

name: Rollei RPX 25
about: Low-speed panchromatic black and white film with high resolving power. Perfect for bright-day long exposures. Verified via Rollei technical data.

name: Rollei RPX 400
about: Traditional high-speed black and white film with a broad tonal range. Manufacturer-verified reciprocity makes it a stable all-around performer.

name: Rollei Superpan 200
about: Extended near-infrared sensitivity. Provides high contrast and excellent sharpness. Verified reciprocity curves allow for technical precision.

name: Ferrania P30
about: Cinematic black and white film with high silver content yielding high contrast and almost no grain. Recreation of a legendary mid-century Italian stock.

name: Flic Film Pan 50
about: Slow-speed fine-grain black and white film re-spooled for precision work. Reciprocity behavior modeled on the Ilford Pan F+ baseline.

name: Kodak T-MAX 100
about: Kodak's T-Grain emulsion allows for incredible sharpness. Sourced from Technical Publication F-4016, showing high efficiency in long exposures.

name: Adox HR-50
about: High-resolution technical film speed-enhanced to 50 ISO. Great for architecture and landscapes. Verified manufacturer data ensures precision.

name: Adox CMS 20 II
about: The sharpest finest grained film in the world. Originally microfilm, it produces grain-less 16x20 prints. Reliability is manufacturer-verified.

name: Lomography Metropolis 400
about: Unique chemical formula with desaturated colors and muted tones. Reliability level 3; uses standard color negative reciprocity rules.

name: Lomography LomoChrome Purple
about: Extraordinary color-shifting film that turns green into purple. Reliability based on community consensus; exposures over 10s may cause color shifts.

name: Flic Film Cinema 50D
about: Fresh Kodak Vision3 50D with rem-jet removed. Iconic cinematic look with daylight balance. Uses standard motion picture reciprocity coefficients.

name: Flic Film Cinema 250D
about: Fresh Kodak Vision3 250D with rem-jet removed. Known for incredible latitude and natural color. Reliable for long exposures with shadow detail.

name: Flic Film Cinema 500T
about: Fresh Kodak Vision3 500T with rem-jet removed. Tungsten balanced. Reciprocity follows the 1.3 exponent; watch for halation in highlight areas.

name: Kosmo Foto Mono 100
about: Panchromatic B&W film with a Soviet-era aesthetic. Re-spooled Fomapan 100; be prepared for significant reciprocity compensation.

name: Reto Amber 400
about: Pre-exposed color film with an amber/orange tint. Reliability based on standard 400-speed metrics; excellent for a warm sunset mood.

name: Dubblefilm Jelly
about: Creative film that produces a mix of colors across each frame. Reciprocity will affect the intensity of the color swirl effect.
